canonical_explanation.text: Oscillatory motion is a periodic motion in which a body moves back and forth about a fixed equilibrium position. Simple harmonic motion (SHM) is a special type of oscillatory motion where the restoring force is directly proportional to the displacement from the mean position and is directed towards it: F = -kx. The displacement in SHM is given by x = A sin(wt + phi), where A is the amplitude, w is the angular frequency, and phi is the initial phase. The velocity is v = Aw cos(wt + phi) and acceleration is a = -w^2 x. The time period T = 2pi/w and frequency f = 1/T. The kinetic energy is KE = (1/2)mw^2(A^2 - x^2), potential energy is PE = (1/2)mw^2 x^2, and total energy TE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2 remains constant. For a spring-mass system, T = 2pi sqrt(m/k). For a simple pendulum, T = 2pi sqrt(l/g). Springs in series combine as 1/k_eff = 1/k1 + 1/k2, and in parallel as k_eff = k1 + k2. In damped oscillations, amplitude decreases over time due to resistive forces. In forced oscillations, an external periodic force drives the system, and resonance occurs when the driving frequency matches the natural frequency, producing maximum amplitude.
rules: SHM displacement: x = A sin(wt + phi).
SHM velocity: v = Aw cos(wt + phi); maximum velocity v_max = Aw at mean position.
SHM acceleration: a = -w^2 x; maximum acceleration a_max = w^2 A at extreme position.
Time period: T = 2pi/w; Frequency: f = 1/T = w/(2pi).
Kinetic energy in SHM: KE = (1/2)mw^2(A^2 - x^2).
Potential energy in SHM: PE = (1/2)mw^2 x^2.
Total energy in SHM: TE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2 = constant.
Springs in series: 1/k_eff = 1/k1 + 1/k2; Springs in parallel: k_eff = k1 + k2.
Damped oscillations: amplitude decreases exponentially with time due to dissipative forces.
Resonance: maximum amplitude when driving frequency equals natural frequency of the system.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of simple harmonic motion?

options.text: A ball bouncing on the floor
A mass attached to a spring oscillating on a frictionless surface
A car moving in a straight line at constant speed
A planet revolving around the sun

questions.explanation_correct: A mass attached to a spring oscillating on a frictionless surface experiences a restoring force proportional to displacement (F = -kx), which is the defining condition for SHM.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A bouncing ball does not have a restoring force proportional to displacement. A car at constant speed is uniform motion, not oscillatory. Planetary revolution is periodic but not SHM. Only the spring-mass system satisfies the SHM condition F = -kx.

questions.question_text: In SHM, the restoring force is:

options.text: Directly proportional to displacement and directed towards the mean position
Directed away from the mean position

questions.explanation_correct: In SHM, the restoring force F = -kx is directly proportional to the displacement x from the mean position and is always directed towards the mean position (indicated by the negative sign).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The restoring force in SHM is not constant; it varies with displacement. It is directly proportional (not inversely) to displacement and is directed towards (not away from) the mean position.

questions.question_text: The displacement of a particle in SHM is given by x = A sin(wt + phi). What does A represent?
questions.explanation_correct: In the equation x = A sin(wt + phi), A represents the amplitude, which is the maximum displacement of the particle from its mean (equilibrium) position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In x = A sin(wt + phi): A is the amplitude (maximum displacement), w is the angular frequency, t is the time, and phi is the initial phase constant. A does not represent angular frequency, time period, or phase constant.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of angular frequency (w) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Angular frequency w is measured in radian per second (rad/s). It is related to the time period by w = 2pi/T and to frequency by w = 2pi f.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hertz is the unit of frequency (f), not angular frequency (w). Metre per second is a unit of velocity, and second is a unit of time. Angular frequency has the unit rad/s.

questions.question_text: The relationship between angular frequency (w) and time period (T) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The angular frequency w = 2pi/T, where T is the time period. This means one complete oscillation (2pi radians) occurs in time T.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct relation is w = 2pi/T. Option A incorrectly puts T in the numerator. Option B multiplies 2pi by T instead of dividing. Option D uses pi instead of 2pi.

questions.question_text: A periodic motion that repeats itself after a fixed interval of time is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A motion that repeats itself at regular time intervals is called periodic motion. The smallest time interval after which the motion repeats is called the time period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rotational motion involves rotation about an axis. Rectilinear motion is motion in a straight line. Projectile motion is motion under gravity. A motion that repeats at fixed time intervals is periodic motion.

questions.question_text: Every oscillatory motion is periodic, but every periodic motion is not necessarily oscillatory.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Every oscillatory motion repeats itself over time (hence periodic), but not every periodic motion is oscillatory. For example, uniform circular motion is periodic but not oscillatory since the object does not move back and forth about a fixed point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Oscillatory motion is always periodic, but periodic motion (like uniform circular motion) need not involve back-and-forth movement about a fixed point.

questions.question_text: The displacement of a particle in SHM is x = 5 sin(4t + pi/6) cm. The angular frequency of the motion is:
questions.explanation_correct: Comparing x = 5 sin(4t + pi/6) with the standard form x = A sin(wt + phi), we get A = 5 cm, w = 4 rad/s, and phi = pi/6. Hence the angular frequency is 4 rad/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In x = A sin(wt + phi), the coefficient of t is the angular frequency w. Here w = 4 rad/s. 5 is the amplitude, pi/6 is the initial phase, and 20 is not directly obtained from the equation.

questions.question_text: If the time period of an oscillation is 0.5 s, the frequency of oscillation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency f = 1/T = 1/0.5 = 2 Hz. The frequency is the reciprocal of the time period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Frequency f = 1/T. With T = 0.5 s, f = 1/0.5 = 2 Hz. Option A confuses T with f. Option B would correspond to T = 1 s. Option D would correspond to T = 0.25 s.

questions.question_text: The phase constant (phi) in the SHM equation x = A sin(wt + phi) determines the ________ of the particle at t = 0.
questions.explanation_correct: The phase constant phi determines the initial displacement (position) of the particle at t = 0. At t = 0, x = A sin(phi), so phi fixes where in its cycle the particle starts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The phase constant phi in x = A sin(wt + phi) fixes the initial condition. At t = 0, x = A sin(phi), so phi determines the initial displacement of the particle.

questions.question_text: The velocity of a particle executing SHM is maximum at:

options.text: Midway between mean and extreme positions

questions.explanation_correct: In SHM, velocity v = Aw cos(wt + phi). The velocity is maximum (v_max = Aw) when the particle passes through the mean position (x = 0), where all energy is kinetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Velocity in SHM is maximum at the mean position, not at the extremes. At extreme positions the velocity is zero and the particle momentarily comes to rest before reversing direction.

questions.question_text: The acceleration of a particle in SHM is maximum at:

options.text: Midway between mean and extreme positions

questions.explanation_correct: In SHM, acceleration a = -w^2 x. The magnitude of acceleration is maximum (a_max = w^2 A) at the extreme positions where displacement x = A is maximum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acceleration in SHM is proportional to displacement (a = -w^2 x). It is maximum at the extremes (x = A) and zero at the mean position (x = 0), not the same everywhere.

questions.question_text: In SHM, the acceleration is related to displacement as:
questions.explanation_correct: In SHM, the acceleration is a = -w^2 x. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is always directed opposite to the displacement, i.e., towards the mean position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct relation is a = -w^2 x. The negative sign is essential as it shows acceleration is always directed towards the mean position. Options without the negative sign or with incorrect powers do not represent SHM.

questions.question_text: A particle in SHM has amplitude 10 cm and angular frequency 5 rad/s. Its maximum velocity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Maximum velocity in SHM is v_max = Aw = 10 cm x 5 rad/s = 50 cm/s. This occurs at the mean position where x = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: v_max = Aw = 10 x 5 = 50 cm/s. Option A divides A by w. Option C divides w by A. Option D multiplies an extra factor. The maximum velocity is 50 cm/s.

questions.question_text: A particle executes SHM with amplitude 4 cm and angular frequency 3 rad/s. The maximum magnitude of acceleration is:
questions.explanation_correct: Maximum acceleration in SHM is |a_max| = w^2 A = (3)^2 x 4 = 9 x 4 = 36 cm/s^2. This occurs at the extreme positions (x = A).
questions.explanation_incorrect: a_max = w^2 A = 9 x 4 = 36 cm/s^2. Option A calculates wA (velocity, not acceleration). Option D gives just w^2. The correct answer is 36 cm/s^2.

questions.question_text: At what displacement from the mean position is the velocity of a particle in SHM half of its maximum velocity? (Amplitude = A)
questions.explanation_correct: In SHM, v = w sqrt(A^2 - x^2). When v = v_max/2 = Aw/2, we get Aw/2 = w sqrt(A^2 - x^2). Squaring: A^2/4 = A^2 - x^2, so x^2 = 3A^2/4, giving x = A sqrt(3)/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v = w sqrt(A^2 - x^2) and setting v = Aw/2: A^2/4 = A^2 - x^2, giving x^2 = 3A^2/4, so x = A sqrt(3)/2. The answer is not A/2, A/sqrt(2), or A/4.

questions.question_text: The total energy of a particle in SHM is:
questions.explanation_correct: The total energy in SHM is TE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2, which depends only on the amplitude and angular frequency, not on the instantaneous displacement. Therefore, total energy remains constant throughout the motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In SHM, kinetic and potential energies interchange, but their sum (total energy) remains constant at all positions. It is not maximum at any particular position and is not zero anywhere.

questions.question_text: At the mean position in SHM, the kinetic energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: At the mean position, x = 0, so PE = (1/2)mw^2 x^2 = 0 and KE = TE - PE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2. The entire energy is kinetic at the mean position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At the mean position, displacement x = 0 and PE = 0, so KE equals the total energy. KE is zero at the extremes, not at the mean position.

questions.question_text: At what displacement from the mean position are the kinetic and potential energies of a particle in SHM equal?
questions.explanation_correct: KE = PE means (1/2)mw^2(A^2 - x^2) = (1/2)mw^2 x^2. This gives A^2 - x^2 = x^2, so 2x^2 = A^2 and x = A/sqrt(2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Setting KE = PE: A^2 - x^2 = x^2 gives x = A/sqrt(2). At x = A, KE = 0 and PE = TE. At x = A/2, KE and PE are not equal. The displacement where KE = PE is A/sqrt(2).

questions.question_text: A particle of mass 0.2 kg executes SHM with amplitude 0.1 m and angular frequency 10 rad/s. The total energy of the particle is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: TE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2 = 0.5 x 0.2 x 100 x 0.01 = 0.1 J. Careful with the squaring: w^2 = 100 and A^2 = 0.01. The total energy is 0.1 J.

questions.question_text: In SHM, the velocity and acceleration of the particle are always in opposite directions.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Velocity and acceleration are in opposite directions only when the particle moves away from the mean position (acceleration decelerates it). When the particle moves towards the mean position, velocity and acceleration are in the same direction (acceleration speeds it up).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. When the particle moves towards the mean position, both velocity and acceleration point towards the mean position (same direction). They are in opposite directions only when the particle moves away from the mean position.

questions.question_text: The displacement of a particle in SHM is given by x = 0.05 sin(20t + pi/3) m. The maximum kinetic energy of the particle of mass 0.5 kg is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: A = 0.05 m, w = 20 rad/s, m = 0.5 kg. KE_max = (1/2)mw^2 A^2 = 0.5 x 0.5 x 400 x 0.0025 = 0.25 J. Make sure to square both w and A correctly.

questions.question_text: If the amplitude of SHM is doubled, the total energy becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: Total energy TE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2. Since TE is proportional to A^2, doubling the amplitude (A -> 2A) makes the total energy (2A)^2/A^2 = 4 times the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: TE is proportional to A^2, so when A doubles, TE increases by a factor of 4. It does not simply double or remain unchanged.

questions.question_text: A particle in SHM has a velocity of 8 cm/s when at a displacement of 3 cm from the mean position, and a velocity of 6 cm/s when at 4 cm from the mean position. The amplitude of the SHM is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v^2 = w^2(A^2 - x^2) for both conditions and dividing to eliminate w^2, we get A = 5 cm. This classic problem requires setting up two equations and solving simultaneously.

questions.question_text: The time period of a spring-mass system is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: For a spring-mass system, the time period T = 2pi sqrt(m/k), where m is the mass and k is the spring constant. A larger mass oscillates more slowly, while a stiffer spring oscillates faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct formula is T = 2pi sqrt(m/k). Option A has m and k inverted. Option C is the incorrect inverse of the pendulum formula. Option D has wrong form entirely.

questions.question_text: The time period of a simple pendulum depends on:

options.text: Length of the pendulum and acceleration due to gravity

questions.explanation_correct: The time period of a simple pendulum is T = 2pi sqrt(l/g). It depends only on the length l of the pendulum and the acceleration due to gravity g. It is independent of mass, amplitude (for small oscillations), and the material of the string.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For small oscillations, T = 2pi sqrt(l/g) depends only on length and g. It is independent of the mass of the bob (unlike a spring-mass system) and amplitude (for small angles).

questions.question_text: A spring of spring constant 200 N/m has a mass of 0.5 kg attached to it. The time period of oscillation is: (Take pi^2 = 10)
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2pi sqrt(m/k) = 2pi sqrt(0.5/200) = 2pi sqrt(1/400) = 2pi / 20 = pi/10 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T = 2pi sqrt(m/k) = 2pi sqrt(0.5/200) = 2pi x (1/20) = pi/10 s. Make sure to correctly compute sqrt(0.5/200) = sqrt(1/400) = 1/20.

questions.question_text: If the length of a simple pendulum is quadrupled, its time period:
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2pi sqrt(l/g). If l becomes 4l, T' = 2pi sqrt(4l/g) = 2 x 2pi sqrt(l/g) = 2T. The time period doubles when length is quadrupled.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since T is proportional to sqrt(l), quadrupling l multiplies T by sqrt(4) = 2. The time period doubles, not quadruples.

questions.question_text: Two springs with spring constants k1 = 100 N/m and k2 = 200 N/m are connected in parallel. A mass of 1 kg is attached. The effective spring constant is:
questions.explanation_correct: For springs in parallel, k_eff = k1 + k2 = 100 + 200 = 300 N/m. In parallel combination, both springs share the load and the effective spring constant is the sum of individual constants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In parallel: k_eff = k1 + k2 = 300 N/m. Option B gives the series combination result (1/k_eff = 1/k1 + 1/k2). For parallel springs, we simply add the spring constants.

questions.question_text: Two springs with spring constants k1 = 100 N/m and k2 = 200 N/m are connected in series. The effective spring constant is:
questions.explanation_correct: For springs in series: 1/k_eff = 1/k1 + 1/k2 = 1/100 + 1/200 = 3/200. So k_eff = 200/3 N/m (approximately 66.7 N/m).
questions.explanation_incorrect: In series: 1/k_eff = 1/100 + 1/200 = (2+1)/200 = 3/200, giving k_eff = 200/3 N/m. Option A is the parallel combination. The series combination always gives a lower effective spring constant than either individual spring.

questions.question_text: The time period of a simple pendulum on the moon (g_moon = g/6) compared to the earth is:
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2pi sqrt(l/g). On the moon, T_moon = 2pi sqrt(l/(g/6)) = 2pi sqrt(6l/g) = sqrt(6) x T_earth. The time period on the moon is sqrt(6) times the time period on earth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since T is proportional to 1/sqrt(g) and g_moon = g/6, T_moon = T_earth x sqrt(g/g_moon) = T_earth x sqrt(6). The period increases by a factor of sqrt(6), not 6.

questions.question_text: The time period of a spring-mass system is independent of ________.
questions.explanation_correct: The time period of a spring-mass system T = 2pi sqrt(m/k) depends only on mass m and spring constant k. It does not depend on gravity (g), unlike a simple pendulum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T = 2pi sqrt(m/k) for a spring-mass system has no g term. Hence, the time period is independent of gravity. This is why a spring-mass system has the same time period on earth and on the moon.

questions.question_text: A simple pendulum of length 1 m has a time period of 2 s on earth. If taken to a planet where g = 4g_earth, the time period will be:
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2pi sqrt(l/g). With g' = 4g: T' = 2pi sqrt(l/4g) = (1/2) x 2pi sqrt(l/g) = T/2 = 2/2 = 1 s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T is proportional to 1/sqrt(g). If g increases by 4 times, T decreases by a factor of sqrt(4) = 2. So T' = 2/2 = 1 s.

questions.question_text: A mass m is attached to a spring of spring constant k. If the mass is increased to 4m, the new time period is:
questions.explanation_correct: T = 2pi sqrt(m/k). With mass 4m: T' = 2pi sqrt(4m/k) = 2 x 2pi sqrt(m/k) = 2T. Doubling the mass by a factor of 4 doubles the time period.
questions.explanation_incorrect: T is proportional to sqrt(m). If m becomes 4m, T' = T x sqrt(4) = 2T. The time period doubles when the mass is quadrupled.

questions.question_text: A simple pendulum has time period T. If it is taken in a lift accelerating upward with acceleration a, the new time period is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a lift accelerating upward with acceleration a, the effective gravitational acceleration is g_eff = g + a (the bob feels heavier). Therefore T' = 2pi sqrt(l/(g+a)), which is shorter than T.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the lift accelerates upward, effective g increases to (g+a), making the pendulum oscillate faster (shorter period). Option B applies for downward acceleration. Option C ignores lift acceleration.

questions.question_text: A spring is cut into two equal halves. The spring constant of each half is:
questions.explanation_correct: When a spring of spring constant k is cut in half, each half has half the original length. Since spring constant is inversely proportional to length (k proportional to 1/l), the spring constant of each half becomes 2k.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Spring constant is inversely proportional to the length of the spring. Halving the length doubles the spring constant. So each half has spring constant 2k, not k/2 or k.

questions.question_text: In damped oscillations, the amplitude of oscillation:
questions.explanation_correct: In damped oscillations, the amplitude decreases with time because energy is continuously lost to the surrounding medium through resistive (dissipative) forces such as friction or air resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In damped oscillations, dissipative forces (friction, air drag) remove energy from the system, causing the amplitude to decrease progressively with time. It does not remain constant or increase.

questions.question_text: The damping force in damped oscillations is proportional to:
questions.explanation_correct: In the simplest model of damped oscillations, the damping force is proportional to the velocity of the oscillating body: F_damping = -bv, where b is the damping constant and v is the velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The restoring force is proportional to displacement, but the damping force is proportional to velocity (F_damping = -bv). The damping force opposes the motion, hence depends on velocity.

questions.question_text: The total energy of a damped oscillator over time:
questions.explanation_correct: In damped oscillations, energy is continuously dissipated by the damping force. Since amplitude decreases with time and total energy is proportional to the square of the amplitude, the total energy decreases continuously.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike ideal SHM where total energy is conserved, in damped oscillations energy is lost to dissipative forces, causing the total energy to decrease continuously over time.

questions.question_text: In damped oscillations, the frequency of oscillation remains exactly the same as the natural frequency of the undamped system.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In damped oscillations, the angular frequency of the damped system is slightly less than the natural frequency: w_d = sqrt(w_0^2 - (b/2m)^2), where b is the damping constant. The frequency decreases slightly due to damping.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Damping slightly reduces the frequency of oscillation compared to the undamped natural frequency. The damped frequency w_d is less than w_0.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an everyday example of damped oscillation?

options.text: A child on a swing being pushed regularly
A car's shock absorber after going over a bump
A tuning fork vibrating in vacuum

questions.explanation_correct: A car's shock absorber is designed to provide damped oscillations. After going over a bump, the spring compresses and the damper dissipates energy, causing the oscillation to die out quickly for a smooth ride.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A child being pushed on a swing is forced oscillation. A clock pendulum is maintained by a mechanism. A tuning fork in vacuum has negligible damping. A shock absorber is a classic example of deliberate damping.

questions.question_text: Forced oscillations occur when:

options.text: A body oscillates freely without any external force
An external periodic force is applied to an oscillating system

questions.explanation_correct: Forced oscillations occur when an external periodic force is applied to an oscillating system. The system then oscillates at the frequency of the applied force, not necessarily at its natural frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Free oscillations occur without external force. Forced oscillations specifically require an external periodic driving force. The system may still experience damping during forced oscillations.

questions.question_text: Resonance occurs when:

options.text: The frequency of the driving force equals the natural frequency of the system
The amplitude of oscillation is minimum

questions.explanation_correct: Resonance occurs when the frequency of the external driving force matches the natural frequency of the oscillating system. At resonance, the amplitude of oscillation is maximum (for a given damping).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resonance is the condition where the driving frequency equals the natural frequency, resulting in maximum amplitude transfer. It does not mean maximum damping, minimum amplitude, or cessation of oscillation.

questions.question_text: At resonance, the amplitude of forced oscillations is:
questions.explanation_correct: At resonance, the driving frequency matches the natural frequency of the system, and the amplitude of the forced oscillation reaches its maximum value. The actual maximum amplitude depends on the amount of damping present.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At resonance, energy transfer from the driving force to the system is most efficient, resulting in maximum amplitude. The amplitude is neither zero nor minimum at resonance.

questions.question_text: A bridge may collapse when soldiers march in step across it because of:

options.text: Resonance between marching frequency and natural frequency of the bridge
Wind blowing at the same time
The material of the bridge being weak

questions.explanation_correct: When soldiers march in step, they apply a periodic force at a fixed frequency. If this frequency matches the natural frequency of the bridge, resonance occurs, and the amplitude of vibration increases dramatically, potentially causing the bridge to collapse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The danger is not just the weight but the rhythmic (periodic) force. If the marching frequency matches the bridge's natural frequency, resonance causes dangerously large oscillations. This is why soldiers break step when crossing bridges.

questions.question_text: In forced oscillations, the steady-state frequency of the system is equal to:

options.text: The natural frequency of the system
The frequency of the external driving force
The average of the natural and driving frequencies

questions.explanation_correct: In the steady state of forced oscillations, the system oscillates at the frequency of the external driving force, regardless of its natural frequency. The natural frequency determines where resonance occurs but not the steady-state oscillation frequency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In forced oscillations, the system is compelled to oscillate at the driving frequency in steady state. The natural frequency only determines the amplitude response (resonance peak), not the oscillation frequency.

questions.question_text: If damping in a system is increased, the amplitude at resonance decreases.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Greater damping dissipates more energy per cycle, which limits the maximum amplitude achievable at resonance. With very heavy damping, the resonance peak becomes broad and flat with a reduced maximum amplitude.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Damping opposes the build-up of amplitude. More damping means more energy dissipation, leading to a smaller resonance amplitude.

questions.question_text: The phenomenon in which the frequency of the driving force equals the natural frequency of the oscillating system, causing maximum amplitude, is called ________.
questions.explanation_correct: Resonance is the phenomenon where the driving frequency matches the natural frequency of a system, leading to maximum energy transfer and hence maximum amplitude of oscillation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the driving frequency matches the natural frequency, the system absorbs energy most efficiently, resulting in maximum amplitude. This phenomenon is called resonance.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT an example of resonance?

options.text: Tuning a radio to a specific station
Shattering of a glass by a singer's voice
A freely falling body under gravity
Vibration of a bridge due to wind at its natural frequency

questions.explanation_correct: A freely falling body under gravity is not oscillatory motion at all, so resonance does not apply. Tuning a radio (electromagnetic resonance), shattering glass (acoustic resonance), and bridge vibration at natural frequency are all examples of resonance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Free fall is linear motion under gravity with no oscillation or periodic driving force. All other options involve a system being driven at or near its natural frequency, which is resonance.

questions.question_text: The kinetic energy of a particle of mass m executing SHM with angular frequency w at displacement x from the mean position is KE = ________.
questions.explanation_correct: The kinetic energy in SHM is KE = (1/2)mv^2 = (1/2)m[w^2(A^2 - x^2)] = (1/2)mw^2(A^2 - x^2). At x = 0, KE = (1/2)mw^2 A^2 (maximum), and at x = A, KE = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v^2 = w^2(A^2 - x^2) in KE = (1/2)mv^2 gives KE = (1/2)mw^2(A^2 - x^2). This shows KE is maximum at the mean position and zero at the extremes.
